If we did this, I think we can clean up the API and instead include a list of files/columns to not include as part of indexing, and call this a RecursiveStaticPathSpec

@jihoonson, the goal here is mainly that the overlord shouldn't rapidly gain and lose leadership if something is wrong. Currently, it does that if the leadership startup throws an exception. So IMO this issues could be solved by waiting for some delay if leadership startup throws an exception.

One thing to keep in mind is making sure we don't block up any threads/executor services that Curator or anything else is using for any other purposes.
btw, I think you should be able to reproduce this rapid leadership cycling situation by just doing a `throw new RuntimeException()` in the TaskMaster leadership startup code.
üëç
@navis can you take a look?
Fixed in #3572; test case added in #3630. Even though the latter isn't merged yet I'll close this since the bug is fixed.

Also please add documentation for the new functions
Also, `LoadBalancingPool` and `ReferenceCouningResourceHandler` should probably get similar fixes; but decided to make that in separate PRs.

Well, this commit does not fix the race condition :) But it couldn't probably be fixed, because as said in "WARNING" somebody may close `ObjectResourceHandler` any time after getting the object from `get()`, that will "invalidate" that object anyway
This un-swallows a bunch of checks but that's probably a good thing

@leventov that makes sense for the specific context of processing threads and i can imaging things being adjusted that way. however StupidPool is used in other places too where same thread might ask for multiple different buffers. my intention with this PR is to solve the problem mentioned in the description.

Thrift Protocol is detected automatically (binaryProtocol, compactProtocol, jsonProtocol is supported)
Batch Ingestion is based on elephant-bird LzoThriftBlockInputFormat
Hope this helps....

@nishantmonu51 I don't think this should block on docs. The original expressions PRs and a few follow ups have gone in without docs already, and behavior has been evolving. I prefer adding docs in a separate PR when we like the behavior.
Filed #3634 for that.

@hamlet-lee there shouldn't be a noticeable performance difference, this is more for data consistency on ingestion side... in some cases it is desired for us to have either all dataSources indexed or none.

Note that item number 3 here is a backwards incompatible interface change to something that can potentially be changed in an extension.  I'm not sure who actually extends the interface, but I suspect it would be either MMX or Imply if anyone.

Sticking with semantic versioning, this change should result in 0.10.x.  Are we ready for the next release to be 0.10?
I'm üëç on these changes.  But we need to discuss the implications of the interface change and agree on versioning strategy.
@justsmoke can we please also add documentation similar to the other extensions and also update extensions.md?

cursory comment: can the name be changed to "diskNormalizedCostBalancer"?

Re: the 0.10 question, this doc: http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/modules.html suggests that cost balancers are not an expected extension point and so the version bump may not be needed. We could also clarify that doc from "suggests" to "says very clearly" as part of this pr.
My feeling is that it's fine to do this change in 0.9.3 since we did not set an expectation in the docs that cost balancer strategies are a stable API for extensions.

IMO since it already had one üëç  then a good solution is for someone else to take a look at the code before 0.9.3.

@cheddar @gianm Yes, code moved in to druid in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3585 is equivalent to the diff currently in https://github.com/metamx/java-util/pull/55  except imports, package name and license.

@gianm @cheddar Sorry for accidentally adding filesmoosher changes along with migration.  I can open a pr to revert filesmoosher changes to make things more aligned with druid-io review process. What do you think?

Actually, using it as a `ThreadLocal` is also incorrect because this isn't something that actually follows the lifecycle of the threads.  If one of the processing threads dies for some unknown reason, that doesn't necessarily mean that we want new objects to be created.

The reason to use `ThreadLocal` is when an object is necessarily tied to the lifecycle of a thread or if the cost of management of those objects is sufficiently small that you don't care about spurious instantiations.  Neither of those statements are true in this case.
:+1: LGTM, @navis when you fix the merge conflicts we can pull this in

Alternate view: Currently we use Sequence mainly (only?) on the query side of things, and QueryableIndexIndexableAdapter is an indexing side thing. Maybe it makes sense to use Sequences there too but currently we largely don't.
Committed addressed patch first. I think I should squash these to rebase on #3630, which is really painful.

On @dclim's "please add documentation" comment, IMO, we don't need this right now.

None of the expression stuff is documented currently. I raised #3634 for this earlier today. We need to start those docs and pay down that debt before 0.9.3, but I think it doesn't need to be in this PR since the API is still in flux. I think it makes sense to work out the API details through further PRs and then write the docs.
@navis, sorry about conflicts from #3630!
@gianm that sounds fine to me, but FYI there is a documentation page (but I don't think it's reachable from anywhere right now!): http://druid.io/docs/0.9.1.1/misc/math-expr.html
@dclim oops, I missed that. Nevermind, in that case I agree this PR should have some additions there. But let's keep it unlinked until we're happy with the API.

Also Sequence is quite heavy-weight and seems to be supposed to be used to iterate/map/filter large objects like segments, subqueries, etc. For Rows maybe another simpler abstraction could be used, something like `CloseableIterable extends Iterable, Closeable`.

btw, that conflict between #3630 and here makes me wonder how we should deal with null strings in the expression language. My first instinct (not having thought about it too much) is that we should take the attitude that Druid doesn't actually generate any nulls from its columns. I'm intending to do something similar in the druid-sql I'm working on, see https://groups.google.com/d/msg/druid-development/3npt9Qxpjr0/IeJQP0YXBQAJ. i.e. if the dimension selector or an extractionFn returns `null` then the expression system could treat that as `""`.
That seems reasonable to me.

@cheddar `ThreadLocal` isn't necessarily tied _only_ with a Thread, it could be tied with a pair of a Thread and some object (i. e. `ThreadLocal` field is not `static`).

I'm pretty sure `StupidPool` is overused in the Druid codebase and could be avoided somewhere. Recently we have issues with GC and OOMs in production which most likely come from `StupidPool`'s "finalized" direct buffers. The issue is probably mitigated by #3629 and #3631, but I'm not sure is gone entirely.

@gianm nevermind it (and it's my fault not checked related issues) and yes, null handling is really confusing and hard-to-fix issue in druid. in expression world, it's more confusing because null was not there in birth.
@dclim updated math-expr
@dclim most of issues described here are fixed in #2836. this can be simple refactoring over it ( or should I merge this into it?)

hm.. we have 'like' math function code of which is copied from hive. would it be better to use somewhere validated code?
@fjy yep, we ran on production env and could see decrease of time but as described in comment, it was not enough for our use case. I'm good to close this.
Any performance numbers?
@fjy documentation is added
@navis there's not too many changes here, I'm fine either way

@navis I'm not familiar with hive's version to know if it does the stuff this version does (we need to split out any exact prefix for the index lookup optimization, and we want to support custom "escape" chars for clauses such as `foo LIKE "bar@%" ESCAPE "@"`). If so and if performance is as good or better‚Ä¶¬†sure. Really I didn't look into it since LIKE parsing is relatively simple.

@leventov can you backport?
@navis can you provide relative numbers or benchmarks for this so acceptance or just closing can be determined?
for example, a 10% improvement is pretty good because if we can get 10 "small" 10% reductions without sacrificing other capacities, that's like a 65% overall reduction in execution time.

Please note the differing license headers on `extendedset` and `bytebuffercollections` files.  `extendedset` is actually a fork of someone else's repository, given that it is a fork already, the statement that it was "licensed to Metamarkets under a CLA" is not true, so we instead opted to keep the same license header.

@cheddar given that, can we split the "purely MMX CLA" into its own PR for easier merging?

I'm a bit concerned about how we can make sure we can maintain a proper licensing header for things that did not originate under a MMX CLA

üëç waiting for travis

The name is "fix resource leaks", but the implementation appears to be just moving things to use try-with-resources or `Closer` instead of `closeQuietly`.  Can you provide some more color on why `closeQuietly` was resulting in resource leaks?

`Closer` was introduced in Guava 14, but hadoop is still using 11, so using it has the potential to cause some compatibility issues.

@cheddar in the original PR "moving things around" is separated from actual resource leak fixes to make them move visible: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3629 fixes themselves: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3629/commits/1375e652bddd140466b80fb5eef8f0698545315e

I think `Closer` is used extensively in the Druid codebase
@leventov Closer is used extensively, but purposefully avoided for any file that Hadoop indexing may touch. Agree with cheddar this needs to be tested for hadoop
@fjy @cheddar thanks, didn't know that. How this testing could be done?
üëç
@drcrallen @cheddar Removed extendedset module.
Do we really need to backport this? It doesn't seem like a critical fix, and there is some risk identified. Can we leave it for 0.9.3? (which #3629 is already marked for)
Just asking because we are pretty late in the rc train and would like to stick to critical issues and regressions.
I'm running internal builds with this patch to ensure it does not fail existing integration test setup.
This page was started but is unreachable: http://druid.io/docs/0.9.1.1/misc/math-expr.html. Should be polished and linked to docs for 0.9.3
